content.webTitle: Eden Hazard happy at Chelsea, insists Guus Hiddink after win at Bournemouth

fields.headline: Eden Hazard happy at Chelsea, insists Guus Hiddink after win at Bournemouth
fields.bodyText: Guus Hiddink believes Eden Hazard is enjoying football once again following his disappointing year, insisting the Belgian is happy to stay at Chelsea next season. Hazard scored twice as Chelsea beat Bournemouth in an entertaining match during which Cesc Fàbregas orchestrated the tempo in midfield, with Pedro and Willian also scoring for the champions. Remarkably, considering Hazard was the PFA Player of the Year last season, these were his first Premier League goals since May 2015. His campaign has been hampered significantly by injury, although there were question marks about his hunger under José Mourinho. In February, Hazard said it would be “difficult to say no to PSG” following speculation linking him with a summer move to Paris, although he has since claimed he is happy at Chelsea. Hiddink, who will be replaced by the Italian Antonio Conte at the end of the European Championship, said of Hazard: “It’s a very bad season, we do not like to neglect the facts. It’s difficult for a talented, high-quality player like Hazard. I think this season he had a very difficult season, falling into injuries coming back, nearly back, playing half a game and then falling back into injuries. It’s frustrating. “Then we said, let’s train well, let’s treat him well and take a little more time so that when you come back you’ll be back well. He showed that today. When he is there fully fit physically and mentally – which is always an influence on each other – then he is one of the best. Whenever he could participate in team training, I noticed that I saw him moving more, very light, very fresh, and he was enjoying it and making jokes when he was playing. He was playing free with no doubt in his mind and any frustrations so this was a good sign for me. “After having a bad season normally you are a little bit touched, a little bit hurt as a player and I think he has the capacity to gain it back in the coming years. I don’t know exactly but he has some more years to go [on his contract]. “What I know he is very happy with everything in Chelsea and around Chelsea. He is very important and if he is fit as he is today showing, not fully fit, he will be very important again next season.” Fàbregastore Bournemouth apart with effective back-flicks and decisive passing, creating three goals, and Hiddink believes the Spaniard excels when in a more advanced position. Chelsea’s next home game is against Tottenham Hotspur, potentially a decisive one for the north London club in the race for the Premier League title, and the away fans on the south coast voiced their appetite for denting Spurs’ hopes. On Fàbregas, Hiddink said: “He has this very quick vision. To have the vision on the pitch and to execute that is the main problem of many players but he has that. When he is a little bit in an advanced position he does not have to do the defensive work so much and he can concentrate a little bit more on his speciality. “He has also, as everybody in the team had, difficult times until December and January when we climbed up. Today I think was a perfect performance of his. He is also important when surrounded by players who can help him defensively, so that he can use his quality, it’s nice to see from him and also from the other players.” Bournemouth created a number of chances during a relatively even first half, but despite Tommy Elphick’s goal Eddie Howe conceded his team had work to do to establish themselves in the Premier League. “We’re learning all the time and we’re learning on the job,” Howe said. “There’s no easy way to become an established Premier League club, there are going to be some tough days. This was one of the best I’ve seen Chelsea play in recent weeks. I just think it’s an overall evolution of the team to progress and become stronger.” Man of the match Cesc Fàbregas (Chelsea)
